title: Air pollution policy should focus on the most vulnerable people, not just the most polluted places
coauthors: Tatyana Deryugina, Nolan Miller, and David Molitor
abstract: Policies aimed at reducing the harmful effects of air pollution on human health typically focus on improving air quality in polluted areas. This column suggests a shift in focus from targeting the most polluted places to serving the most vulnerable people. Basing air quality regulations on pollution levels may be less valuable than reducing air pollution in regions with vulnerable populations. Programmes that reduce poverty or improve access to health care may also lessen the recipientsâ€™ susceptibility to acute pollution exposure.

title: The Illinois Workplace Wellness Study: Reply to Dr. Goetzel
Workplace Wellness: New Study Finds No Changes in Health Care Costs
Tools to Address Illinois Revenue: Increasing Sin Taxes
abstract: In this report, I estimate the revenue that could be generated by increasing Illinois sin taxes on cigarettes, alcohol, and gambling. I discuss the efficiency and distributional effects of those taxes, as well as potential savings from a reduction in cigarette and alcohol consumption.
